channel.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
channel.description:
Hello there, So I've done everything needed to decompile, and I can run the client, and compile. But, when I compile, I get the 100 errors. I've tried doing it on my own .jar which I've already got a decompiled version of (off here), and I've realized that the decompiling wasn't done successfully. I've tried using different decompilers, but all of them had errors, and I think one of the best ones is "jd-gui". Now what I'm asking for, is a successful way to decompile a .jar and be able to compile it, and then open using the recompiled version. If you may please help me and take some of your time, then that'd be greatly appreciated!!
Thanks, Nael

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @shabba_56 shabba 56
item.description:
@shabba_56 wrote:

I found this site http://www.javadecompilers.com wasnt to bad getting to test a few new decompilers but they don’t decompile small class files witch is a pain

Read full topic

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

the process of decompiling is actually pretty complex especially if the control flow is severely fucked up by ZKM (what Jagex uses to obfuscate their game client). you best bet is using the best decompiler available which i believe is currently Procyon. the README will explain why it is superior: https://bitbucket.org/mstrobel/procyon/wiki/Java%20Decompiler

Read full topic

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @shabba_56 shabba 56
item.description:
@shabba_56 wrote:

I had similar problems decompiling a .jar I ended up extracting every .class file from the .jar file and signally decompiling each class file this is a very long and painful process. also with decompiling your client might need libs files or clientlibs depending on the client revision, using eclips or netbeans as above is best, I used jode and jad to decompile

Read full topic

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

Decompiling does not give actual source code, especially in large projects like a rsps client.

Read full topic

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @xX4m4zingXx xX4m4zingXx
item.description:
@xX4m4zingXx wrote:

If you decompile a jar you will always have errors. I don’t know why it is(i am sure that there are people who know that), but i think you can fix the errors in eclipse.
I am not sure if you need this one or this one

Read full topic

item.title: Decompiling .jar clients without errors?
item.dc:creator: @Nael Nael
item.description:
@Nael wrote:

Hello there,
So I’ve done everything needed to decompile, and I can run the client, and compile. But, when I compile, I get the 100 errors. I’ve tried doing it on my own .jar which I’ve already got a decompiled version of (off here), and I’ve realized that the decompiling wasn’t done successfully. I’ve tried using different decompilers, but all of them had errors, and I think one of the best ones is “jd-gui”. Now what I’m asking for, is a successful way to decompile a .jar and be able to compile it, and then open using the recompiled version. If you may please help me and take some of your time, then that’d be greatly appreciated!!

Thanks,
Nael

Read full topic
